awd_titl_txt: Shaping the Future of Geoscience Education Research: Synthesizing Results and Articulating Future Directions
awd_abstract_narration:
The project is investigating the current status of geoscience education research (GER), focusing on undergraduate education and building on recent reports on Discipline-Based Education Research (DBER). The project supports a collaborative effort by the geoscience education research community to identify and synthesize the accomplishments, results, and claims of GER, compile an annotated list of methods used in such research, and recommend future research directions and ways to support such efforts. The project includes engagement of the GER and broader geoscience education communities through a three-day workshop as well as virtual activities to engage the community before, during, and after the workshop. The project website supports community-wide engagement and dissemination.  The project is providing a focus on the current status and future directions of GER and ultimately, as research translates into practice, in shaping undergraduate geoscience education at the individual, institutional, and national level. The project supports the development of the geoscience education research community through the workshop and virtual opportunities for engagement.

The project includes crowd-sourced engagement of the GER and broader geoscience education communities through a three-day workshop, as well as virtual opportunities to engage the community before, during, and after the workshop.  Virtual activities include virtual discussions before the workshop, a virtual poster session and discussion during the workshop, and feedback and comments on draft products after the workshop. The project website is hosted by the National Association of Geoscience Teachers (NAGT). Primary deliverables from the project include resources focused on the methods used in GER, what has been learned to date in GER, critical topics and questions for future GER work, and strategies for building the GER community and support new researchers in the field.

por.por_cntn:
The project gathered together a community of researchers and educators interested in geoscience education research to begin to characterize the current state of Geoscience Education Research. We hosted a webinar on “Discipline-Based Education Research in the Geosciences” and led a workshop at the Earth Educators’ Rendezvous in July 2016 for researchers and educators on “Synthesizing Geoscience Education Research: Where are we? What is the path forward?” With geoscience education research dating back several decades, it was not possible in a short workshop to summarize everything that has been done. Nonetheless, the workshop was an opportunity to begin to tackle the following questions:  (1) What have we already learned from geoscience education research; (2) What are the most useful methods to carry out geoscience education research? How should new research be done?; and (3) What are our priorities for future research and how can we best support the community of geoscience education researchers?

Intellectual Merit: Small group discussions at the workshop about the results of geoscience education research in seven topical areas (students' conceptual understanding; cognitive domain and problem solving; instructional strategies to improve geoscience learning; affective domain and metacognition; access and success; nature of science / nature of geoscience; and professional development of college/university educators) were wide-ranging with more questions than answers. However participants agreed on the following points: (1) Active learning works. (2) Professional development workshops are effective in helping educators transform and improve their abilities as teachers. (3) The geoscience field is a leader in teaching students to think spatially (for example, in three-dimensions) and across large time scales. (4) Students learn more when they are not simply taught content, but are also taught how to organize new information, to reflect on the information and why it is important, and to practice different ways of representing concepts. Some students use these strategies on their own, but others can be taught how to use them. In general, this approach is called metacognition. Participants also discussed directions of future research and acknowledged the value of considering the strength of evidence for particular research results, from single studies in one classroom to work that investigates multiple courses, different institutions, and diverse populations. This workshop was the first step in a longer process to synthesize the results of geoscience education research. An important follow-on from the workshop will be a special issue of the Journal of Geoscience Education, Synthesizing Results and Defining Future Directions of Geoscience Education Research.

Workshop participants also made recommendations for building and supporting the geoscience education research community. These recommendations include the following: Identify and improve pathways that lead to a career in geoscience education research; encourage and engage new researchers with entry-level publications, webinars, mentorships, and other activities; develop a “toolbox” of research methods and resources that education researchers could use; compile and publish lists of different research methods, instruments, and statistical methods that researchers could use; organize data gathered by previous studies and make it accessible so that the community can make better use of existing data; seek interdisciplinary collaborations in research efforts, especially cognitive scientists and education researchers in other disciplines; support the translation of research results into educational practice; and help re-design instructional materials such as textbooks and web-based resources so that they reflect the current state of the research.
